## Reviewer's Guide Refactors OPML import into a dedicated service in backend/feed_service.py with iterative, URL-validated processing and weighted SSE progress reporting, wires the blueprint to that service, adds SSE-driven progress UI for OPML import and feed refresh, tightens URL validation throughout feed processing, and extends tests (including SSE and Playwright coverage) to match the new behavior. ### File-Level Changes | Change | Details | Files | | ------ | ------- | ----- | | Refactor OPML import into backend/feed_service with iterative processing, URL validation, weighted progress, cache invalidation, and tab management. |
  • Introduce import_opml service that reads the OPML stream once, parses it with defusedxml, and coordinates the full import flow.
  • Replace recursive outline traversal with _process_opml_outlines_iterative using an explicit stack to avoid RecursionError and support progress tracking.
  • Add URL validation helpers (validate_link_structure, is_valid_feed_url) to enforce http/https schemes and reject malformed URLs during import.
  • Implement _determine_target_tab, _cleanup_empty_default_tab, and _invalidate_import_caches to select or create target tabs, remove unused default tabs, and bulk-invalidate caches for affected tabs.
  • Batch-commit new feeds and perform initial fetches with _batch_commit_and_fetch_new_feeds, emitting weighted SSE progress events for the fetching phase.
  • Count feeds up front via _count_feeds_in_opml and compute a 50/50 processing vs fetching progress scale exposed over SSE via announcer.
| `backend/feed_service.py`
`backend/constants.py` | | Simplify the OPML blueprint into a thin HTTP wrapper around the new service and clean up OPML export and autosave helpers. |
  • Remove in-blueprint recursive import logic, tab-selection, cache invalidation, and fetch-on-import responsibilities, delegating them to feed_service.import_opml.
  • Adjust import_opml route to validate the uploaded file, extract tab_id, call the service, and translate its (result, error) tuple into JSON HTTP responses.
  • Keep and slightly tidy OPML export and autosave helpers, including more explicit exception handling and logging during export generation.
| `backend/blueprints/opml.py` | | Add SSE-driven progress reporting for bulk feed refresh and ensure reliable completion signaling. |
  • Extend update_all_feeds to announce an initial progress event, per-feed progress updates keyed by processed feed count, and a final progress_complete event over SSE.
  • Track successful_count, total_feeds, and affected_tab_ids while processing futures, and update logging to reflect successful vs total feeds.
  • Standardize error logging in feed processing to use sqlalchemy.exc.SQLAlchemyError where appropriate and logger.exception for richer tracebacks.
| `backend/feed_service.py`
`backend/test_app.py` | | Harden URL handling in feed metadata and item processing to avoid unsafe or malformed links. |
  • Use validate_link_structure when updating a feed's site_link, logging and discarding potentially unsafe links instead of storing them.
  • Apply validate_link_structure to entry links in _collect_new_items so items with missing or invalid links are skipped with warnings.
  • Adjust tests that exercise feed processing and item creation to cover the new URL validation behavior and time-handling paths.
| `backend/feed_service.py`
`backend/test_app.py` | | Introduce a sticky progress bar UI and SSE handling on the frontend for OPML import and bulk feed refresh operations. |
  • Add a sticky progress container with status text and HTML bar in index.html and style it in style.css to remain visible below the header.
  • Expose showProgress, updateProgress, and hideProgress helpers in ui.js to manipulate the progress UI.
  • Wire app.js to show progress and start a fallback timeout when triggering OPML import or refresh-all, update the bar from SSE progress events, and hide it on progress_complete or error.
  • Normalize handling of affected_tab_ids from SSE events by converting them to numbers, invalidating loadedTabs, refetching tabs metadata, and reloading affected active tabs.
  • Implement a progress fallback timer in app.js that hides the progress bar if SSE events stall, preventing the UI from getting stuck.
  • Update tests to assert the new SSE contract and frontend behavior, including a Playwright test (marked flaky/skip) that validates end-to-end progress UI for import and refresh.
| `frontend/index.html`
`frontend/js/ui.js`
`frontend/js/app.js`
`frontend/style.css`
`backend/test_app.py`
`test_progress.py` | | Update and align tests and documentation with the new OPML import and progress behavior. |
  • Switch OPML-import-related patches from backend.blueprints.opml.fetch_and_update_feed to backend.feed_service.fetch_and_update_feed to match the refactor.
  • Adjust multiple backend tests to account for new return values, SSE event payloads, and minor signature or logging changes in update_all_feeds and import_opml.
  • Add test_opml_import and test_progress coverage for OPML import behavior and SSE progress, while skipping the flaky Playwright test in CI.
  • Document the feature in CHANGELOG and clarify TODO entry for OPML import/export robustness and security.
| `backend/test_app.py`
`test_opml_import.py`
`test_progress.py`
`CHANGELOG.md`
`TODO.md` | ### Assessment against linked issues | Issue | Objective | Addressed | Explanation | | ------ | ------- | ----- | ----- | | https://github.com/sheepdestroyer/SheepVibes/issues/238 | Implement an unobtrusive visual status indicator and progress bar for OPML/import feeds operations. | ✅ | | | https://github.com/sheepdestroyer/SheepVibes/issues/238 | Implement an unobtrusive visual status indicator and progress bar for refreshing all feeds operations. | ✅ | | ### Possibly linked issues - **#41**: PR’s refactored OPML import now returns tab_id and tab_name in the final JSON response, resolving the issue. ---
Tips and commands #### Interacting with Sourcery - **Trigger a new review:** Comment `@sourcery-ai review` on the pull request. - **Continue discussions:** Reply directly to Sourcery's review comments. - **Generate a GitHub issue from a review comment:** Ask Sourcery to create an issue from a review comment by replying to it. You can also reply to a review comment with `@sourcery-ai issue` to create an issue from it. - **Generate a pull request title:** Write `@sourcery-ai` anywhere in the pull request title to generate a title at any time. You can also comment `@sourcery-ai title` on the pull request to (re-)generate the title at any time. - **Generate a pull request summary:** Write `@sourcery-ai summary` anywhere in the pull request body to generate a PR summary at any time exactly where you want it. You can also comment `@sourcery-ai summary` on the pull request to (re-)generate the summary at any time. - **Generate reviewer's guide:** Comment `@sourcery-ai guide` on the pull request to (re-)generate the reviewer's guide at any time. - **Resolve all Sourcery comments:** Comment `@sourcery-ai resolve` on the pull request to resolve all Sourcery comments. Useful if you've already addressed all the comments and don't want to see them anymore. - **Dismiss all Sourcery reviews:** Comment `@sourcery-ai dismiss` on the pull request to dismiss all existing Sourcery reviews. Especially useful if you want to start fresh with a new review - don't forget to comment `@sourcery-ai review` to trigger a new review! #### Customizing Your Experience Access your [dashboard](https://app.sourcery.ai) to: - Enable or disable review features such as the Sourcery-generated pull request summary, the reviewer's guide, and others. - Change the review language. - Add, remove or edit custom review instructions. - Adjust other review settings. #### Getting Help - [Contact our support team](mailto:support@sourcery.ai) for questions or feedback. - Visit our [documentation](https://docs.sourcery.ai) for detailed guides and information. - Keep in touch with the Sourcery team by following us on [X/Twitter](https://x.com/SourceryAI), [LinkedIn](https://www.linkedin.com/company/sourcery-ai/) or [GitHub](https://github.com/sourcery-ai).

## Summary of Changes Hello @sheepdestroyer, I'm Gemini Code Assist[^1]! I'm currently reviewing this pull request and will post my feedback shortly. In the meantime, here's a summary to help you and other reviewers quickly get up to speed! This pull request significantly enhances the robustness and security of the OPML import and feed refresh processes. It addresses potential recursion depth issues, improves user feedback with a weighted progress scale, and strengthens URL validation to mitigate Cross-Site Scripting (XSS) vulnerabilities. ### Highlights * **Iterative OPML Processing**: Replaced recursive outline processing with a stack-based iterative approach in `backend/feed_service.py` to prevent `RecursionError`. * **Weighted Progress Scaling**: Implemented a 50/50 continuous progress scale for OPML imports (processing vs. fetching). * **Security (XSS Prevention)**: Hardened `xmlUrl` validation to allow only `http` and `https` schemes. * **SSE Reliability**: Added `progress_complete` signals to all service exit paths and normalized tab ID types in the frontend. * **Code Cleanup**: Removed redundant recursive logic and unused imports from `backend/blueprints/opml.py`.
Using Gemini Code Assist
The full guide for Gemini Code Assist can be found on our [documentation page](https://developers.google.com/gemini-code-assist/docs/review-github-code), here are some quick tips. Invoking Gemini You can request assistance from Gemini at any point by creating a comment using either `/gemini ` or `@gemini-code-assist `. Below is a summary of the supported commands on the current page. Feature | Command | Description --- | --- | --- Code Review | `/gemini review` | Performs a code review for the current pull request in its current state. Pull Request Summary | `/gemini summary` | Provides a summary of the current pull request in its current state. Comment | @gemini-code-assist | Responds in comments when explicitly tagged, both in pull request comments and review comments. Help | `/gemini help` | Displays a list of available commands. Customization To customize Gemini Code Assist for GitHub experience, repository maintainers can create a configuration file and/or provide a custom code review style guide (such as PEP-8 for Python) by creating and adding files to a `.gemini/` folder in the base of the repository. Detailed instructions can be found [here](https://developers.google.com/gemini-code-assist/docs/customize-gemini-behavior-github). Limitations & Feedback Gemini Code Assist may make mistakes. Please leave feedback on any instances where its feedback is incorrect or counter productive. You can react with :thumbsup: and :thumbsdown: on @gemini-code-assist comments. If you're interested in giving your feedback about your experience with Gemini Code Assist for Github and other Google products, sign up [here](https://google.qualtrics.com/jfe/form/SV_2cyuGuTWsEw84yG). You can also get AI-powered code generation, chat, as well as code reviews directly in the IDE at no cost with the [Gemini Code Assist IDE Extension](https://cloud.google.com/products/gemini/code-assist).

Gemini can make mistakes, so double check it and [use code with caution](https://support.google.com/legal/answer/13505487).

📝 Walkthrough ## Walkthrough Moves OPML import into a service with iterative (stack-based) OPML processing, SSE progress events including `progress_complete` and a 50/50 processing-vs-fetch split, tightens URL validation to http/https, and wires frontend progress UI with a fallback timer and targeted tab reloads. ## Changes |Cohort / File(s)|Summary| |---|---| |**Changelog & Notes**
`CHANGELOG.md`, `TODO.md`|Add 2026-01-29 changelog entry for OPML import & progress; update TODO note to reference refactor, SSE progress, and XSS/URL hardening.| |**API Blueprints**
`backend/blueprints/opml.py`|Replace in-file recursive OPML logic with delegation to `backend.feed_service.import_opml`; simplify `/import` route; add SQLAlchemyError handling in `/export`.| |**Feed service & constants**
`backend/feed_service.py`, `backend/constants.py`|Add `import_opml(opml_file_stream, requested_tab_id_str)` implementing SafeET parsing, iterative outline traversal, on-demand tab creation, batch commit & per-feed fetch, http/https URL validation, SSE `progress` and `progress_complete`, and new `SKIPPED_FOLDER_TYPES`.| |**Frontend JS**
`frontend/js/app.js`, `frontend/js/ui.js`|Import/show/update/hide progress helpers; add progress fallback timer; start/clear fallback during import/refresh; handle SSE `progress` and `progress_complete`; perform targeted tab reloads based on SSE payloads.| |**Tests & E2E**
`backend/test_app.py`, `test_progress.py`|Rewire tests/mocks to new service paths and updated payload shapes; add SSE progress unit test; add Playwright E2E `test_opml_import_and_feed_refresh_progress` (skipped in CI) validating UI progress and fetch refresh progress.| ## Sequence Diagram(s) ```mermaid sequenceDiagram participant Client participant Blueprint as OPML Blueprint participant Service as feed_service.import_opml participant DB as Database participant SSE as SSE/Client Client->>Blueprint: POST /api/opml/import (file, tab id) Blueprint->>Service: import_opml(file_stream, requested_tab_id_str) Service->>Service: parse OPML (SafeET), count feeds (stack-based) Service->>SSE: emit "progress" (processing %) Service->>DB: create tabs/feeds (batch commit) Service->>SSE: emit "progress" (50% -> fetching) loop per-feed Service->>DB: commit feed record Service->>Service: fetch_and_update_feed(feed) Service->>SSE: emit "progress" (incremental) end Service->>SSE: emit "progress_complete" Service->>Blueprint: return result JSON (counts, affected_tab_ids) Blueprint->>Client: 200 OK with result ``` ## Estimated code review effort 🎯 4 (Complex) | ⏱️ ~45 minutes ## Possibly related PRs - sheepdestroyer/SheepVibes#251 — Moves OPML import into `feed_service`, adds SSE progress and iterative processing (strong overlap). - sheepdestroyer/SheepVibes#233 — Earlier blueprint/service split and OPML import/export refactor (implementation overlap). - sheepdestroyer/SheepVibes#244 — OPML parsing safety and XML/URL hardening (parsing/security overlap). ## Poem > 🐇 I stacked the outlines, one hop at a time, > Progress beacons pulsed in tidy rhyme, > I guarded HTTP paths with careful sight, > Tabs and feeds aligned, then blinked to light, > A rabbit cheers — the import finished right.

## PR Reviewer Guide 🔍 #### (Review updated until commit https://github.com/sheepdestroyer/SheepVibes/commit/a9e91756b75cb91da6150a0d266a562be371ec52) Here are some key observations to aid the review process:
**🎫 Ticket compliance analysis ✅** **[238](https://github.com/sheepdestroyer/SheepVibes/issues/238) - PR Code Verified** Compliant requirements: - Unobtrusive visual status updates for OPML import and feed refresh. - Progress bar for these operations. Requires further human verification: - Verify in-browser UX (progress bar placement, unobtrusiveness, and behavior across navigation/refresh). - Verify SSE-driven progress updates behave correctly under slow networks/large OPML imports (no stuck UI, no premature hiding).
⏱️ Estimated effort to review: 4 🔵🔵🔵🔵⚪
🧪 PR contains tests
🔒 No security concerns identified
⚡ Recommended focus areas for review

Performance Building `all_existing_feed_urls_set` via `Feed.query.all()` loads all feeds into memory; on large datasets this can be slow and memory-heavy. Consider querying only the `url` column (or using streaming/pagination) to avoid loading full ORM objects. ```python all_existing_feed_urls_set = {feed.url for feed in Feed.query.all()} ```
SSE Flooding `update_all_feeds` emits an SSE progress message for every completed feed. With many feeds, this can spam the client and the server’s SSE channel; consider throttling (e.g., every N feeds / time-based) or coalescing updates. ```python status_msg = f"({processed_count}/{total_feeds}) Checking: {feed_obj.name}" announcer.announce( msg=f"data: {json.dumps({'type': 'progress', 'status': status_msg, 'value': processed_count, 'max': total_feeds})}\n\n" ) ```
UX Regression The progress fallback timeout hides the progress UI after 15 seconds without progress events. For long-running imports/refreshes with sparse progress updates, this may hide the UI even though the operation is still running, causing confusing UX. Consider increasing the timeout, making it adaptive, or showing a “still working” state instead of hiding. ```javascript function _startProgressFallback() { _clearProgressFallback(); progressFallbackTimeoutId = setTimeout(() => { hideProgress(); }, PROGRESS_FALLBACK_TIMEOUT_MS); } ```

`Biome useIterableCallbackReturn rule documentation`

💡 Result:

`useIterableCallbackReturn` is a Biome linter rule (`lint/suspicious/useIterableCallbackReturn`) that **enforces consistent return behavior in callbacks passed to iterable/array methods**—i.e., callbacks should **always return a value** for methods that require it, and **not return a value** for methods where a return is meaningless (like `forEach`). It’s **recommended (enabled by default)**, **available since Biome v2.0.0**, has **no auto-fix**, and defaults to **severity: error**. [1]

### Methods covered
**Callback must return a value**: `every`, `filter`, `find`, `findIndex`, `findLast`, `findLastIndex`, `flatMap`, `map`, `reduce`, `reduceRight`, `some`, `sort`, `toSorted`, and `Array.from` (when called on `Array`). [1]

**Callback must not return a value**: `forEach`. [1]

**Note:** async and generator callbacks are ignored (they always return a `Promise` / `Generator`). [1]

### Configuration (`biome.json`)
```json
{
  "linter": {
    "rules": {
      "suspicious": {
        "useIterableCallbackReturn": "error"
      }
    }
  }
}
``` [1]

Sources: Biome rule docs page [1] and the JavaScript rules index listing the rule [2].  

**References:** [1], [2]

The progress calculation for OPML import can be inaccurate. The `processed_count` includes all processed outlines (feeds, folders, etc.), while `total_feeds_to_import` only includes outlines with a `xmlUrl`. If an OPML file has many folders or other non-feed outlines, `processed_count` can exceed `total_feeds_to_import`, causing the progress value to go beyond its intended maximum for the processing phase and making the status message confusing (e.g., "Processing feed 15/10...").

I suggest two changes:
1. Cap the `progress_val` to ensure it doesn't exceed `OPML_IMPORT_PROCESSING_WEIGHT`.
2. Update the `status_msg` to be less specific about feeds to avoid confusion.

```python
def _calculate_and_announce_progress(processed_count, total_feeds_to_import,
                                     last_announced_percent):
    """Calculates progress and announces it if significant change occurred."""
    if total_feeds_to_import > 0:
        # Cap progress value, as processed_count can exceed total_feeds_to_import.
        progress_val = min(OPML_IMPORT_PROCESSING_WEIGHT,
                         (processed_count *
                          OPML_IMPORT_PROCESSING_WEIGHT) // total_feeds_to_import)
    else:
        progress_val = OPML_IMPORT_PROCESSING_WEIGHT

    current_percent = progress_val
    should_announce = (processed_count == 0
                       or processed_count >= total_feeds_to_import
                       or (current_percent != last_announced_percent
                           and current_percent % 5 == 0)
                       or processed_count % 20 == 0)

    if should_announce:
        status_msg = f"Processing OPML... ({processed_count} outlines analyzed)"

For improved robustness, it would be beneficial to handle potential `IntegrityError` race conditions here, similar to how it's handled in the `_get_or_create_nested_tab` function. If two processes attempt to create the default tab simultaneously, the current implementation will raise a `SQLAlchemyError` and fail the import for the second process. By specifically catching `IntegrityError`, you can gracefully handle this race condition by rolling back the session and then fetching the tab that was created by the other process. This would make the default tab creation more robust.

```python
                except sqlalchemy.exc.IntegrityError:
                    db.session.rollback()
                    logger.info(

                        default_tab_name_for_creation,

                        # was_created remains False, as this process didn't create it.
                    else:

                        logger.error("OPML import: Failed to create or find default tab '%s' after race.", default_tab_name_for_creation)
                        return (None, None, False, ({"error": "Failed to create a default tab for import."}, 500))

![high](https://www.gstatic.com/codereviewagent/high-priority.svg)

There is a potential for data loss here in a race condition scenario. When `db.session.flush()` fails with an `IntegrityError` (e.g., two processes try to create the same tab folder simultaneously), `db.session.rollback()` is called. This rollback reverts the entire transaction, which includes any `Feed` objects that were added to the session via `_process_opml_feed_node` but not yet committed.

These feed objects, while still present in the `newly_added_feeds_list`, become detached from the session and will not be committed later. This results in silent data loss for the feeds that were being processed before this race condition occurred.

A way to address this is to use nested transactions (savepoints) to isolate the tab creation attempt. This would allow you to roll back just the failed `flush` without discarding the entire session's state.

Here's a conceptual example:
```python
db.session.add(new_folder_tab)
s = db.session.begin_nested()
try:
    db.session.flush()
except sqlalchemy.exc.IntegrityError:
    s.rollback() # Roll back only the savepoint
    # The main session is still active. Now fetch the tab created by the other process.
    existing_tab = Tab.query.filter_by(name=folder_name).first()
    if existing_tab:
        return existing_tab.id, existing_tab.name
    # This path would be highly unusual.
    raise

# If flush succeeds, the nested transaction will be part of the main transaction.
return new_folder_tab.id, new_folder_tab.name
```
This approach ensures that a race condition on tab creation doesn't cause data loss for already processed feeds.

The mocked return value for `update_all_feeds` is slightly inaccurate. The actual function in `feed_service.py` returns a `set` for `affected_tab_ids`, but the mock provides a `list` (`[1]`). While this test passes because `list([1])` and `list({1})` both result in `[1]`, it's better for mocks to accurately reflect the function's signature for clarity and future-proofing. Please change this to a set.

![security-high](https://www.gstatic.com/codereviewagent/security-high-priority.svg) ![high](https://www.gstatic.com/codereviewagent/high-priority.svg)

The OPML import process is executed synchronously within the Flask request-response cycle. This process involves making multiple external network requests to fetch and update feeds (via `import_opml_service`). Since these requests are performed sequentially and can take a significant amount of time (especially with a 10-second timeout per fetch), an attacker can upload an OPML file with many feeds to tie up a Flask worker for an extended period. This can lead to worker exhaustion and a denial of service for the entire application. 

**Recommendation:** Move the feed fetching and processing logic to a background task (e.g., using a task queue like Celery or a separate background thread) and return a response to the user immediately. The UI can then monitor progress via the existing SSE stream.

![security-high](https://www.gstatic.com/codereviewagent/security-high-priority.svg) ![high](https://www.gstatic.com/codereviewagent/high-priority.svg)

Similar to the OPML import, the `update_all_feeds` function executes synchronously and blocks the Flask worker until all feeds are refreshed. Although it uses a thread pool to parallelize fetches, the main request thread still waits for all threads to complete (via `concurrent.futures.as_completed`). For a large number of feeds, this will likely exceed the WSGI worker timeout (typically 30-60 seconds), leading to failed requests and worker exhaustion. 

**Recommendation:** Execute the refresh process in a background task and return an immediate acknowledgment to the client.

![security-medium](https://www.gstatic.com/codereviewagent/security-medium-priority.svg) ![medium](https://www.gstatic.com/codereviewagent/medium-priority.svg)

The `update_all_feeds` function creates a new `ThreadPoolExecutor` for every request to the refresh endpoint. There is no global lock or limit on the number of concurrent refresh processes. An attacker can spam the refresh endpoint to force the server to create a large number of threads and perform many concurrent network operations, potentially exhausting system resources (memory, thread handles, file descriptors) and causing a denial of service or system crash.

**Recommendation:** Implement a global lock or a concurrency limit to ensure that only one refresh process runs at a time, or use a singleton worker pool to manage all refresh tasks.

![medium](https://www.gstatic.com/codereviewagent/medium-priority.svg)

The logic for handling `SKIPPED_FOLDER_TYPES` appears to have changed from the previous implementation. The old code would skip a folder of a skipped type *and* all its children. This new iterative version skips creating a tab for the folder but proceeds to process its children under the current tab. This might lead to unintended imports if the skipped folder types (e.g., Netvibes' "Webnote" or "LinkModule") contain outlines that are not valid feeds. The previous behavior of skipping the entire branch seemed safer. Was this change in behavior intentional? Please clarify the intended behavior for these skipped folder types.

def _batch_commit_and_fetch_new_feeds(newly_added_feeds_list,
                                      total_feeds_to_import,
                                      processed_feed_count):
    """Commits new feeds and fetches them, with progress updates."""
    if not newly_added_feeds_list:
        return True, None

    try:
        db.session.commit()

        # Incorporate processed_feed_count into progress reporting so that
        # overall progress remains monotonic across the two import phases.
        if total_feeds_to_import:
            overall_progress_pct = (
                float(processed_feed_count) / float(total_feeds_to_import)
            ) * 100.0
        else:
            overall_progress_pct = 0.0

        logger.info(
            "OPML import: Successfully batch-committed %s new feeds "
            "(%s/%s feeds processed so far, %.2f%% of total).",
            len(newly_added_feeds_list),
            processed_feed_count,
            total_feeds_to_import,
            overall_progress_pct,
        )

        total_to_fetch = len(newly_added_feeds_list)

## Code Review

This pull request significantly improves the robustness and user experience of OPML imports and feed refreshes by migrating from a recursive to an iterative approach for OPML processing, which prevents potential `RecursionError` issues, and by adding weighted progress reporting via SSE. It also includes security hardening on URL validation. A security audit covering `backend/blueprints/opml.py`, `backend/feed_service.py`, `frontend/js/app.js`, `frontend/js/ui.js`, `frontend/index.html`, `backend/constants.py`, and `frontend/style.css` found no vulnerabilities. The code is well-structured, especially the refactoring of import logic into `feed_service`. Minor suggestions for improvement include clarifying a confusing constant redefinition and addressing the use of broad exception handlers.

**issue (bug_risk):** Using `sqlalchemy.exc.*` without importing the `sqlalchemy` module will raise a `NameError`.

Several functions catch `sqlalchemy.exc.IntegrityError` / `sqlalchemy.exc.SQLAlchemyError`, but only the individual exception classes are imported from `sqlalchemy.exc`. Without importing `sqlalchemy` itself in this module, `sqlalchemy` will be undefined when the exception is raised, so the handler won’t run and a `NameError` will occur. Either import the `sqlalchemy` package (e.g. `import sqlalchemy`) or change the handlers to use the imported names directly (e.g. `except IntegrityError:` / `except SQLAlchemyError:`).

## Code Review

This pull request significantly refactors the OPML import and feed refresh functionalities to enhance robustness, user experience, and security. Key changes include migrating the OPML parsing to a stack-based iterative approach in `backend/feed_service.py` to prevent recursion depth issues, and implementing a weighted, continuous progress bar for both OPML imports and feed refreshes using Server-Sent Events (SSE). Security is improved by hardening `xmlUrl` validation to allow only `http` and `https` schemes, and by sanitizing URLs for logging to prevent XSS. The OPML import logic, along with related helper functions for tab management and feed processing, has been moved from `backend/blueprints/opml.py` to `backend/feed_service.py` for better modularity. Error handling across the `feed_service` has been refined by replacing broad `Exception` catches with `sqlalchemy.exc.SQLAlchemyError` and using `logger.exception` for automatic stack trace inclusion. The frontend (`frontend/index.html`, `frontend/js/app.js`, `frontend/js/ui.js`, `frontend/style.css`) has been updated to display the new progress bar and handle SSE events for real-time updates during these operations, including a fallback mechanism for progress display. Additionally, new `SKIPPED_FOLDER_TYPES` have been defined in `backend/constants.py` for more comprehensive OPML folder skipping, and various test files (`backend/test_app.py`, `test_opml_import.py`, `test_progress.py`) have been updated to reflect these changes, including new tests for progress events and URL validation.

## Code Review

This pull request significantly improves the robustness, security, and user experience of the `OPML` import and feed refresh features, notably by migrating from a recursive to an iterative approach for `OPML` parsing and adding `SSE`-based progress reporting. The code is also well-structured, moving business logic to a dedicated service layer. However, a critical security concern is that the implementation of these processes is synchronous and blocking within the `Flask` request-response cycle, posing a high risk of Denial of Service (`DoS`) via worker exhaustion, and the lack of concurrency control for the refresh process can lead to resource exhaustion. Additionally, clarification is requested regarding a subtle change in behavior when handling skipped folder types during `OPML` import that could lead to unintended imports.
